questions.neutral: Feels cooler down here, doesn't it?

hobby.message: Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?
Political literature still whispering to you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Cooler than outside.
I used to fly drones sometimes.
Crowds ruined most of the old flying spots.
Not safe to linger there anymore.
Yeah, it does.
I’m into FPV drone flying, when there’s space for it.
Harder now with protests everywhere near the old industrial zones.
Signal interference messed up my gear last weekend.
Anyone out there knows they’re being watched, too.
Feels nice down here.
I usually clear my head flying FPV drones in the warehouses.
The whole zone’s crowded since the ration leaks came out.
Too many protestors and way too much static on the airwaves.
Lost my drone signal twice last time—risky now.
Just have to wait for it to settle down.
Definitely cooler. Needed a break after today.
I fly freestyle FPV drones—used to be easy to find quiet space.
But after the exposé, everyone’s out in the warehouse district with their own comms.
Crowd traffic wrecked my video link, almost crashed into a wall.
I used to go to clear my head, unwind a bit.
Now it’s riskier, between surveillance and the protests.
Still go sometimes, can’t quite give it up.
Yeah, it’s a relief. My head’s still buzzing from last flight.
I’m big on freestyle FPV drone flying—been doing it for years.
Picked it up back when the city started tightening things and everyone wanted a release.
Now, since the ration exposé, the warehouse spots are full of protest crowds and rogue transmitters.
Lost signal more times last weekend than in a year.
People are tense, looking for someone to blame, even for just flying.
Funny—used to be a place to get away from the system, but now it’s at the center of everything.
Still, while I’m flying, there’s a few seconds where nothing else matters.
hobby_answer: Digital mostly. Analog gets risky these days.
The warehouse zone is crowded now. Too many signals, too much attention.
After the data leaks, even drone flights stand out on the system.
I keep a low profile. Not worth risking equipment or getting flagged.
Digital now. Analog gets scanned way too quickly around here.
I flew last weekend, but had to cut it short.
Everyone's nervous since the exposé, even in the out-of-bounds spots.
Signal was messy—protesters running their own comms everywhere.
Not as relaxing as before. Feels watched, even out there.
Mostly digital. Analog gets too much interference and scrutiny lately.
Tried flying at the usual spot last week—too many people after all that rationing news.
A bunch of protest groups moved in; crowded the airwaves.
Lost control once, almost crashed—never happened to me before.
Now public areas feel tight, like everyone's on edge.
Used to clear my head. Now it's just stress.
Digital. Analog used to be fun, but now attracts system audits fast.
Went to fly last weekend, right after the exposé dropped.
The old warehouse area was packed with angry protesters and their rigs.
Every other signal was jammed—my drone lagged all over the place.
Had to land early rather than risk someone noticing extra signals.
Flying was how I processed things. Now it feels risky.
Feels like the city is shrinking, even in the forgotten zones.
Miss when you could fly and disappear for a while.
Digital for now. Analog frequencies are basically city-owned surveillance.
After the resource exposé, my usual flying spot was flooded with protesters.
Had to dodge protestors, rogue signals, and even grassroots jammers last weekend.
Someone almost logged my wristband ping—I had to spoof my location.
Used to love drifting over empty concrete. Now airspace is as tense as the streets.
I nearly crashed twice. Not my fault, just chaos everywhere.
Flying was how I dealt with...everything. Now it just reminds me I can't.
If my brother was around, he'd laugh at how tightly wound everyone is.
Funny, the system is distracted, but everything feels more exposed than ever.
